reviewText:
Every once in a while you come across a game that is more than the sum of its parts yet defies traditional definition. Such is the case with The Old Tree, a minimal and simplistic point and click adventure that takes less than a minute to download, less than twenty minutes to complete, and leaves a lasting impression.

The gameplay has you clicking on interactive objects while the camera follows a small squid like alien through several unsettling and atmospheric scenes. You could say this is more interactive art than actual gameplay ‚Äì it is a little creepy, and the game‚Äôs experimental nature is clear from its opening.

Yet this doesn‚Äôt detract from the experience. The art is clearly the major draw for this game ‚Äì and the minimal design aesthetic works well in its favour. There are several small puzzles that work on a light versus darkness factor, and this is usually very easily discovered. There really is no frustration. It feels familiar and yet different.

The sound is also minimal and simplistic, with an unnerving background drone-like soundtrack. It repeats often, but I think this also is to The Old Tree‚Äôs benefit. I‚Äôm not sure what it‚Äôs trying to accomplish, but I feel urged on to completion and at the same time just slightly rattled.

While there really isn‚Äôt anything to say for the game‚Äôs replayability or even for the game‚Äôs controls ‚Äì The Old Tree is an easy recommend. Being available for free helps ‚Äì but I feel it‚Äôs important to recommend games that are just a little different than the norm. And in that ‚Äì The Old Tree really works.

7.0/10.

The Old Tree is an atmospheric puzzle game. As a newly born alien, instinctively walk the strange world that surround you towards an uncertain destination, solving puzzles to continue forward.

Pros: The eerie and the unknown meet with beautifully handdrawn-like graphics and atmospheric music. You have absolutely no idea what you're trying to accomplish, just that you must go on, bypass the obstacles that block you, and proceed. There is no fighting, to violence, no dialog and no age barriers to this game, just the feeling of discovery.

reviewText:
The Old Tree is a short puzzle-solving game made by Red Dwarf Games, I'll start out by saying I enjoyed this game a lot, and have replayed it so many times Ive lost count, the game is pretty short but if you can forgive it for that its a great little play.

So you play as some sort of small alien recently hatched from an egg and you must help it on its way, the puzzles are in the vain of the old point and click games that I played growing up so that was a nice bit of nostalgia for me.

There is no story exactly, more or less you are just trying to help your little friend get to his / her destination

The art style I must say is incredible, its varies through the different areas and really helps each location define itself, the art has a certain charm to it.

The sound is somewhat simple but well used to help draw you into the game and the journey that you are undertaking.

I'll leave you with this, The Old Tree is a great little game and will no doubt keep you interested throughout its duration, and its absolutely free if that's not a good reason to check it out I don't know what is....so Why not give it a try.

(Like all my reviews I do not put a score as it is my belief that games like all forms of art are subjective and therefore it is impossible to afix a number to them)

reviewText: Some people might say this game is just a pretty and sweet short game with no underlying message. They are dead wrong. My god, right from the word go I saw the metaphors leaping from the game. The beauty of this game is that even the developers play along and pretend its about nothing more than a sweet little alien! This game deflty covers everything from the concept of cloud seeding by the government to suffrage rights for women in an oppressive world. There's even hints of fear mongering and it raises really interesting questions about quantum physics and its role in your relationship with your parents. You could easily burn a good 5-6 hours on this game, probably more if you want to really dig into the issues it raises. I also found if I recorded the background music and played it backwards at half speed, I could hear the (pretty obvious) voice of Margret Thatcher telling me it was time to get in touch with my inner sexy horse whisperer. This game helped me reidentify with my true calling, and I believe it can do the same for you. 10/10

reviewText:
Simplistic and slightly creepy.

This is a point-and-click game that uses a very lovely greyscale and rather creepy artstyle, where you follow the adventure of a strange egg-like thing on its adventures through The Old Tree. It's very specific on how the game wants their sequence of clicks, often leaving the player (me) confused and unengaged while trying to continue through. There is a lot of waiting implemented, where you have to either wait for things to be in position in order to complete a room. I restarted the game to get to a stage that I thought that I messed up, but only to later find that it's just very very specific, and that replaying the game is very boring and not as interesting as its first impression is. The muscis sets the nice creepy atmosphere in its more subtle notes, leaving you to ignore it in the background until it stops and gives some unease.

Overall, it's nice to play if you've got the 15 minutes to spare, but there isn't really a lot to it. I wouldn't really reccommend it. This is a very simple game with a linear storyboard that has little explanation or substance to draw from. But if you'd like to experience the intrigue that it can provide you mood-wise, it's worth considering to play, especially because it's free.

This game, in theory, is a good game.

However, the game does this for you, making the numerous movement segments very boring, since all you can do is watch this little white blob move across the screen. I give the gameplay a 1/10

Overall, I would give this game a 4/10, because there are some interesting mechanics. With some touching up, this could become much more than it is. However, I would not play it again in its current state.

Review For The Old Tree

You may see that I've only played this game for 30 minutes... that's how long the game is. You may be thinking, wow, a half hour game, how dumb. You sir, are wrong.

Alright, so you may or may not be this alien, you are definitely following it. There is no story, no background story at least, you are just this alien that is trying to get back to space. Now, what do you do? Control the alien? Nope. You are controlling the environment around him or her, which is surprising cool.

The graphics don't need to be good, but they are, well at least the environment is, especially in the cave areas. Basically, the alien moves to a certain point and you have to try to find a way to get him/her to progress the level. It is a puzzle game, but it's a point and click puzzle game. Some of the puzzles are really simple, leading to a 3 second progression time and others had me for as long as about 10 minutes (the water one especially) and the puzzle difficulty are the right level, which is the best. It's a free-to-play game, so you can't beat that and it takes about 1 minute to install, this game is fun. No music however, but sound effects which makes the game a lot more mysterious.

You don't grow any bond on the alien but you do feel bad for him, you have that part where you're despirately wishing that he will find a way home. 30 minutes worth of gameplay is enough for this game, no story and just a ton of puzzles for maybe an hour more would be a little boring. No multiplayer neither a title screen, if there was one complaint I had about the game was that there are no options or title screen, that would have been nice to mess around with. There's no title for the game when you are playing either however, an Adobe 11 message is what fills your screen.

For a free-to-play, 30 minute, puzzle game (no spoilers) but a quick but enjoyable ending, point and click, no music but errie feel, alien loving, bee crushing, soup making, water cranking, bee-water-carrying, this game will give you nothing less than a fun and good time, is it replayability worth? Yup, I do have to say.

Your imagination is instantly peaked when you start to play as an alien blob-like thing. The Old Tree is a short game that takes very little time to complete, however, it inspires many different feelings throughout the course of the game.

Gameplay:
My playthrough took about 20 minutes, which I have noticed is about the average for most people. The moves encompassed the 'w,s,a,d' buttons (really, mostly just the 'a and d' buttons) and your mouse. For this game, those movements worked perfectly to get you from point A to point B.

Graphics:
The developers have done a very good job keeping your focus on the alien-baby you are controlling, with darker undertones for the background. This accentuates the vivid coloring of your character. I thought the graphics were well done with a sort of 'drawn on' effect.

Audio:
The music for this game is phenomenal! The melodies of course changed with different scenes, but did not take away from the experience in anyway. Instead, the music only enhanced the action!  The songs themselves did more for the general ambience of the game then everything else (gameplay/graphics).

Storyline:
This game has a very basic storyline that is really easy to follow. It seemed to me as though is was kind of a twist to the point and click genre. Your alien-baby is on rails throughout the game, and you only move ahead once you can sort out the puzzle. The puzzles are simplistic for the most part and do not take a lot of time to get through, so the overall flow of the game is not broken up.

There are so many ways to experience this game, and I think most people will have varying opinions on what it all is supposed to mean. To me, it started out symbolizing fear. Fear of the unknown, and what was to come for such a tiny creature. It then moved into more of a feeling of triumph, and the knowledge that one can do anything, as long as the will and the effort are there. With a game that takes under half an hour to complete, the playthrough is still a very pleasant occasion. Overall, I believe that this game is completely worth it, and I would highly recommend it, especially because it is offered for free.

Review For The Old Tree

You may see that I've only played this game for 30 minutes... that's how long the game is. You may be thinking, wow, a half hour game, how dumb. You sir, are wrong.

Alright, so you may or may not be this alien, you are definitely following it. There is no story, no background story at least, you are just this alien that is trying to get back to space. Now, what do you do? Control the alien? Nope. You are controlling the environment around him or her, which is surprising cool.

The graphics don't need to be good, but they are, well at least the environment is, especially in the cave areas. Basically, the alien moves to a certain point and you have to try to find a way to get him/her to progress the level. It is a puzzle game, but it's a point and click puzzle game. Some of the puzzles are really simple, leading to a 3 second progression time and others had me for as long as about 10 minutes (the water one especially) and the puzzle difficulty are the right level, which is the best. It's a free-to-play game, so you can't beat that and it takes about 1 minute to install, this game is fun. No music however, but sound effects which makes the game a lot more mysterious.

You don't grow any bond on the alien but you do feel bad for him, you have that part where you're despirately wishing that he will find a way home. 30 minutes worth of gameplay is enough for this game, no story and just a ton of puzzles for maybe an hour more would be a little boring. No multiplayer neither a title screen, if there was one complaint I had about the game was that there are no options or title screen, that would have been nice to mess around with. There's no title for the game when you are playing either however, an Adobe 11 message is what fills your screen.

For a free-to-play, 30 minute, puzzle game (no spoilers) but a quick but enjoyable ending, point and click, no music but errie feel, alien loving, bee crushing, soup making, water cranking, bee-water-carrying, this game will give you nothing less than a fun and good time, is it replayability worth? Yup, I do have to say.

I went in with a low expectations of the game, and I could only say that I'm glad I did. I don't have many complaints about the premise of the game and its puzzle mechanics, but as for the entire game itself... it leaves many things to be desired.

The main problem with the game is that it lacks any form of development, i.e. the baby alien you're playing as stays a baby until the end, and after going through a simple series of puzzles, you finish the game without any form of conclusion or ending. For me, playing through this game did not leave me with any sense of satisfaction or accomplishment.

I think the game has potential, but that potential was wasted with the game's lack of content. If you have time to spare and want to see a very basic indie game with good puzzle mechanics, then by all means try it out. Otherwise, move on and spend your 15 minutes playing some other game that's more worthwhile.

This game is free, so why are you reading this review instead of playing it? Anyway, for those that want a little bit more information here we go:-

This is an odd little 'on rails' 'puzzle' game. Do not get overly excited though, as the whole game is completable in about 10 minutes (well what do expect for free?).

You play as a weird little 4 limbed octopus type alien creature in a surreal world, well I say 'play as', but really it just moves along when it stops you use your mouse to complete a puzzle to get the alien to move again. The game world consists of a few dark tunnels, a kitchen, a lobby and couple of outside bits mostly in hand drawn looking blacks and greys with the odd little smudge of faded colour here and there. Overall the visuals are fairly unique and have an 'indie' look to them which you will either like (a bit) or hate.

There is a simple yet eerie ambient sound track in the background which helps add to the limited atmosphere and is not unpleasant to listen to. Game play wise you progress along a predetermined course and solve simple puzzles to reach your goal, which is just freedom I guess.

The puzzles are as straight forward as clicking a glowing red dot in the dark to switch on a light, to working out how to get into a flood-able section of tunnel and then re-flood it to get onto the ceiling amongst other stuff. It's certainly not going to strain your brain although there are often no clues as to what you have to do, so sometimes it's just a case of trail and error or just click on everything you can see and see if it reacts. It's not as frustrating as it sounds as you'll work out how to solve each puzzle within an attempt or two.

If they were charging say ¬£0.70 for the game I'd say it was over priced and only worth about ¬£0.10. But as it is free I think you should add it to your collection, even if it's just so you can complete it and increase your (probably) horrifically low 'Avg. Game Completion Rate' found in your profile.
